segment.source: Understanding AppLocker allow and deny actions on rules (Windows 10)
segment.target: Understanding AppLocker allow and deny actions on rules (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic explains the differences between allow and deny actions on AppLocker rules.
segment.target: This topic explains the differences between allow and deny actions on AppLocker rules.

segment.source: Understanding AppLocker allow and deny actions on rules
segment.target: Understanding AppLocker allow and deny actions on rules

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic explains the differences between allow and deny actions on AppLocker rules.
segment.target: This topic explains the differences between allow and deny actions on AppLocker rules.

segment.source: Allow action versus deny action on rules
segment.target: Allow action versus deny action on rules

segment.source: Unlike Software Restriction Policies (SRP), each AppLocker rule collection functions as an allowed list of files.
segment.target: Unlike Software Restriction Policies (SRP), each AppLocker rule collection functions as an allowed list of files.

segment.source: Only the files that are listed within the rule collection are allowed to run.
segment.target: Only the files that are listed within the rule collection are allowed to run.

segment.source: This configuration makes it easier to determine what will occur when an AppLocker rule is applied.
segment.target: This configuration makes it easier to determine what will occur when an AppLocker rule is applied.

segment.source: You can also create rules that use the deny action.
segment.target: You can also create rules that use the deny action.

segment.source: When applying rules, AppLocker first checks whether any explicit deny actions are specified in the rule list.
segment.target: When applying rules, AppLocker first checks whether any explicit deny actions are specified in the rule list.

segment.source: If you have denied a file from running in a rule collection, the deny action will take precedence over any allow action, regardless of which Group Policy Object (GPO) the rule was originally applied in.
segment.target: If you have denied a file from running in a rule collection, the deny action will take precedence over any allow action, regardless of which Group Policy Object (GPO) the rule was originally applied in.

segment.source: Because AppLocker functions as an allowed list by default, if no rule explicitly allows or denies a file from running, AppLocker's default deny action will block the file.
segment.target: Because AppLocker functions as an allowed list by default, if no rule explicitly allows or denies a file from running, AppLocker's default deny action will block the file.

segment.source: Deny rule considerations
segment.target: Deny rule considerations

segment.source: Although you can use AppLocker to create a rule to allow all files to run and then use rules to deny specific files, this configuration is not recommended.
segment.target: Although you can use AppLocker to create a rule to allow all files to run and then use rules to deny specific files, this configuration is not recommended.

segment.source: The deny action is generally less secure than the allow action because a malicious user could modify the file to invalidate the rule.
segment.target: The deny action is generally less secure than the allow action because a malicious user could modify the file to invalidate the rule.

segment.source: Deny actions can also be circumvented.
segment.target: Deny actions can also be circumvented.

segment.source: For example, if you configure a deny action for a file or folder path, the user can still run the file from any other path.
segment.target: For example, if you configure a deny action for a file or folder path, the user can still run the file from any other path.

segment.source: The following table details security concerns for different rule conditions with deny actions.
segment.target: The following table details security concerns for different rule conditions with deny actions.

segment.source: Rule condition
segment.target: Rule condition

segment.source: Security concern with deny action
segment.target: Security concern with deny action

segment.source: Publisher
segment.target: Publisher

segment.source: A user could modify the properties of a file (for example, re-signing the file with a different certificate).
segment.target: A user could modify the properties of a file (for example, re-signing the file with a different certificate).

segment.source: File hash
segment.target: File hash

segment.source: A user could modify the hash for a file.
segment.target: A user could modify the hash for a file.

segment.source: Path
segment.target: Path

segment.source: A user could move the denied file to a different location and run it from there.
segment.target: A user could move the denied file to a different location and run it from there.

segment.source: Important: If you choose to use the deny action on rules, you must ensure that you first create rules that allow the Windows system files to run.
segment.target: Important: If you choose to use the deny action on rules, you must ensure that you first create rules that allow the Windows system files to run.

segment.source: AppLocker enforces rules for allowed applications by default, so after one or more rules have been created for a rule collection (affecting the Windows system files), only the apps that are listed as being allowed will be permitted to run.
segment.target: AppLocker enforces rules for allowed applications by default, so after one or more rules have been created for a rule collection (affecting the Windows system files), only the apps that are listed as being allowed will be permitted to run.

segment.source: Therefore, creating a single rule in a rule collection to deny a malicious file from running will also deny all other files on the computer from running.
segment.target: Therefore, creating a single rule in a rule collection to deny a malicious file from running will also deny all other files on the computer from running.
